 Then I charge you with being clueless!
 
 
Points out "gill slits" in human embryos.

 
 Human embryos do have "gill slits". Before anyone calls me stupd, let me point out that what humans have are not gill slits, they aren't even slits; but since the term they used is in double quotes - "gill slits" - it indicates non-standard usage of the term. And human embryos do have structures in their pharyngeal region that are homologous to the structures that give rise to fish gills.
 
 What human embryos actually have are pharyngeal pouches, pharyngeal arches, and ectodermal grooves. The ectodermal grooves and pharyngeal pouches grow towards one another and end up being separated by only a thin branchial plate. If the plate ruptures - as it does in aquatic vertebrates like fish - then it's called a pharyngeal slit. So all that separates a human embryo's setup from a pharyngeal slit is the lack of rupturing of the thin branchial plate separating the pharyngeal pouch and ectodermal groove.
 
 As far as the human embryo's pharyngeal stuctures being related to those of fish that produce gills, just read the article "The Origin of the Parathyroid Gland", by Masataka Okabe and Anthony Graham. They provide multiple lines of evidence that support their relatednes.
 
 
Says that although the Haeckel drawings were wrong, that there are still clear similarities in early embryos, when in fact there are almost no similarities.

 
 Quite false, as anyone who has taken an embryology class (like the one I just finished last semester) would know. The are NUMEROUS similarities in the early embryos of vertebrates, such as chickens, pigs, and humans, especially in the pharyngula stage.
